title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Product Manager, Cloud Networking at Google) outlines how Google Cloud applies AI-aware networking to improve AI inference performance. He highlights GKE Inference Gateway, specialized load balancing using inference-specific metrics, and network-level service extensions (guardrails) to reduce latency, improve GPU utilization, and cut wasted compute.
bullets: Use inference-specific metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) instead of CPU to identify least-loaded replicas for routing.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the network reuse prefill computations to reduce cold starts and GPU work.
Body-based routing and LoRA adapter awareness enable routing by model/context to appropriate replicas.
Service Extensions insert API management and AI guardrails into the traffic path so prompts/responses can be sanitized at the edge.
Implemented with GKE Inference Gateway, Cloud Load Balancing, and Google Kubernetes Engine to streamline developer APIs and governance.
takeaways: Visibility into GPU-specific metrics changes capacity and power planning—better utilization can lower peak power and overall energy/cost per inference.
Reducing cold starts and intelligently routing traffic can cut transient power spikes and improve latency/SLA adherence for critical workloads.
Network-level guardrails can prevent wasted GPU compute (and associated energy/cost) by dropping invalid requests before they reach models.
Adopting AI-aware networking affects data center sizing, rack-level GPU allocation, cooling and backup power provisioning due to different utilization patterns.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, NVIDIA GeForce’s video showcases the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and #RTXOn, with footage credited to DigitalDreamsyt. It’s presented as a visual and performance-focused demo highlighting NVIDIA’s latest GPU features.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet.
Showcase of DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation.
Presented with #RTXOn (NVIDIA ray-tracing enabled).
Footage/credit: DigitalDreamsyt.
Published by NVIDIA GeForce on 2026-01-14.
takeaways: Advanced GPU features (DLSS 4, MFG, RTX) signal higher-performance GPU workloads—expect greater power draw and cooling needs for similar demo/play scenarios.
Data centers and edge facilities hosting GPU-accelerated graphics or AI should validate electrical capacity and rack cooling for sustained peak loads.
Energy-efficiency tech like DLSS may improve frames per watt in some workflows—worth testing to quantify potential reductions in compute time and power for high-fidelity graphics tasks.
Procurement and lifecycle planning should account for demand for high-end GPUs, with attention to supply chain and critical mineral availability for scaling deployments.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this GE Vernova video focuses on assessing the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and outlining next-step actions at end-of-life. It points viewers to a detailed resource for rotor EOL decisions and positions GE Vernova as a provider helping electrify and decarbonize energy systems.
bullets: Video topic: anticipating remaining life of steam turbine rotors and recommended next steps at end-of-life.
Directs viewers to a GE Vernova resource on rotor EOL (https://vernova.is/rotor-EOL).
Calls to subscribe to GE Vernova’s YouTube channel and follow their social profiles.
Frame: GE Vernova presenting itself as leading electrification while working to decarbonize energy.
takeaways: For grid and data center operators, rotor life assessment is critical for reliability planning and avoiding unexpected outages.
Early EOL evaluation informs maintenance, overhaul, or replacement decisions that affect availability and capital timing.
Use vendor resources (like the linked GE Vernova page) to inform technical and commercial options for steam turbine assets.
Communications from OEMs can help align decarbonization goals with asset management and lifecycle strategies.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the KPMG podcast discusses how the luxury goods market is evolving around experiences, personalization, ESG/responsible-luxury practices and a growing segment of ‘affordable luxury.’ The episode highlights Poland’s still-growing but fragmented luxury market, shifts in consumer groups (including Gen Z and aspirational buyers), the role of luxury tourism and hotels, and forward-looking themes such as AI, craftsmanship and sustainability.
bullets: Global trends: ‘luxury fatigue,’ concentration of spending (top 2% = 40% of market) and rise of affordable luxury.
Customer focus on personalization and exclusive experiences; Gen Z prefers experiences over ownership.
ESG and responsible luxury gaining importance (e.g., eco-leathers, certifications).
Luxury applications in hotels, film and tourism are shaping brand-building and demand patterns.
Poland: market continues to grow but remains dispersed; future drivers include AI, craftsmanship and young creators.
takeaways: AI and advanced personalization trends imply rising compute, low-latency services and higher power/cooling demand — plan capacity and cooling for increased data-center loads.

Stronger ESG expectations from luxury brands/customers create demand for certified renewable energy, transparent energy sourcing and energy-storage solutions — opportunity for renewables + storage projects and supply contracts.
Growth in luxury hospitality and tourism in Poland suggests localized peak loads and resiliency needs (backup power, microgrids, resilient substations) at premium properties and destinations.
Concentrated high-value customer segments and premium digital services favor edge deployments and high-availability infrastructure — consider distributed edge facilities and reliability SLAs.

As sustainability and supply-chain transparency rise, stakeholders should monitor material needs for renewables/storage (implications for critical-minerals sourcing and lifecycle reporting) when structuring long-term energy and procurement strategies.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, since 1927 PJM Interconnection has made reliability its top priority and this video explains how PJM works to make sure electricity is there when you need it. The clip appears to be an overview of PJM’s longstanding operational focus on keeping the power system reliable for customers and stakeholders.
bullets: Highlights PJM Interconnection’s long history (since 1927) and emphasis on reliability.
Aims to explain how PJM works to ensure electricity is available when needed.
Framed as an educational overview of PJM’s role in maintaining system reliability.
No transcript was provided with the video description.
takeaways: Treat PJM’s reliability focus as a key factor when planning critical-load arrangements and resilience measures.
Coordinate with PJM on operational expectations and emergency procedures to support uninterrupted power for data centers.
When adding renewables or storage, engage PJM resources and guidance to ensure those assets support system reliability.
Monitor PJM outreach and materials for updates that could affect grid operations, planning, and backup power strategies.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames grid modernization as a need to balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. The company emphasizes digital-first power-grid technologies designed to improve stability, reduce downtime and optimize performance at every level.
bullets: Power systems must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency as capacity grows for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy positions digital technologies at the core of its grid solutions.
Focus areas highlighted: improved stability, reduced downtime, and system-wide performance optimization.
Solutions are intended to operate across multiple levels of the power system (from grid to end assets).
takeaways: Prioritize digital upgrades (controls, monitoring, analytics) to boost stability and minimize outages for substations and data centers.
When expanding capacity for renewables/storage, require flexibility and efficiency as central design criteria to avoid reliability trade-offs.
Evaluate vendors on their ability to deliver integrated, digital-first solutions that optimize performance across the whole power system.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, resilient industries depend on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy says it works with customers and partners to build smarter systems that improve productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Focus areas: energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy emphasizes collaboration with customers and partners.
Goal: smarter systems that raise productivity and operational reliability.
Sustainability is highlighted as an operational objective.
Resource link provided for more information.
takeaways: Grid and substation teams should prioritize energy-efficiency and digital upgrades to boost reliability and operational productivity.
Data center operators can leverage process optimization and integrated digital tools to improve uptime and sustainability metrics.
Renewables and storage projects benefit from systems-level integration that enhances performance and supports sustainable operations.
Partnering with technology providers can accelerate implementation of smarter systems and reduce deployment risk.
Maintain an operational focus on sustainability — including supply-chain and materials considerations — when planning infrastructure upgrades.
